title: J86-3001

sentences.text: In this paper we explore a new theory of discourse structure that stresses the role of purpose and processing in discourse .

In this theory , discourse structure is composed of three separate but interrelated components : the structure of the sequence of utterances -LRB- called the linguistic structure -RRB- , a structure of purposes -LRB- called the intentional structure -RRB- , and the state of focus of attention -LRB- called the attentional state -RRB- .
The linguistic structure consists of segments of the discourse into which the utterances naturally aggregate .
The intentional structure captures the discourse-relevant purposes , expressed in each of the linguistic segments as well as relationships among them .
The attentional state is an abstraction of the focus of attention of the participants as the discourse unfolds .
The attentional state , being dynamic , records the objects , properties , and relations that are salient at each point of the discourse .
The distinction among these components is essential to provide an adequate explanation of such discourse phenomena as cue phrases , referring expressions , and interruptions .
The theory of attention , intention , and aggregation of utterances is illustrated in the paper with a number of example discourses .
Various properties of discourse are described , and explanations for the behaviour of cue phrases , referring expressions , and interruptions are explored .
This theory provides a framework for describing the processing of utterances in a discourse .

Discourse processing requires recognizing how the utterances of the discourse aggregate into segments , recognizing the intentions expressed in the discourse and the relationships among intentions , and tracking the discourse through the operation of the mechanisms associated with attentional state .
This processing description specifies in these recognition tasks the role of information from the discourse and from the participants ' knowledge of the domain .

Entity-theory_of_discourse_structure.label: theory of discourse structure
aliases: a new theory of discourse structure
Entity-theory_of_discourse_structure.description: The theory of discourse structure refers to a linguistic framework that analyzes discourse as composed of three interrelated components: the linguistic structure of utterances, the intentional structure capturing discourse-relevant purposes, and the attentional state reflecting the focus of attention of participants, emphasizing the roles of purpose and processing in understanding discourse dynamics.

mentions.local_name: a new theory of discourse structure

Entity-this_paper.label: this paper
Entity-this_paper.description: This paper presents a new theory of discourse structure that emphasizes the interrelated components of linguistic structure, intentional structure, and attentional state, and explores their roles in discourse processing.

Entity-theory_of_attention__intention__a.label: theory of attention, intention, and aggregation of utterances
aliases: theory of attention, intention, and aggregation of utterances
Entity-theory_of_attention__intention__a.description: The theory of attention, intention, and aggregation of utterances is a framework for understanding discourse structure that emphasizes the interrelated roles of linguistic sequences, the intentions behind utterances, and the dynamic focus of attention among participants during discourse.

mentions.local_name: theory of attention, intention, and aggregation of utterances

Entity-theory.label: theory
Entity-theory.description: The theory refers to a framework for understanding discourse structure, which includes the linguistic structure, intentional structure, and attentional state, emphasizing the roles of purpose and processing in the aggregation and interpretation of utterances.

Entity-intentional_structure.label: intentional structure
Entity-intentional_structure.description: The intentional structure refers to a component of discourse structure that captures the purposes relevant to the discourse, expressed within linguistic segments and their interrelationships.

Entity-three_separate_but_interrelated_c.label: three separate but interrelated components
Entity-three_separate_but_interrelated_c.description: The phrase 'three separate but interrelated components' refers to the three essential elements of discourse structure in the proposed theory, which are the linguistic structure (the sequence of utterances), the intentional structure (the structure of purposes), and the attentional state (the focus of attention during discourse).

Entity-purpose_and_processing.label: purpose and processing
Entity-purpose_and_processing.description: The term 'purpose and processing' refers to the integral components of a new theory of discourse structure that emphasizes the significance of intentional structures and the mechanisms of discourse processing in understanding how utterances are organized and interpreted within communication.

Entity-the_discourse.label: the discourse
Entity-the_discourse.description: The discourse refers to the structured sequence of utterances and their interrelated components, including linguistic structure, intentional structure, and attentional state, which together facilitate the understanding and processing of communication among participants.

Entity-this_theory.label: This theory
Entity-this_theory.description: This theory refers to a new framework of discourse structure that emphasizes the interrelated components of linguistic structure, intentional structure, and attentional state to explain the processing of utterances in discourse.

Entity-purpose.label: purpose
Entity-purpose.description: In the context of discourse structure, 'purpose' refers to the discourse-relevant intentions that are expressed within linguistic segments and the relationships among them, as part of the intentional structure in the theory presented in the paper.

Entity-the_paper.label: the paper
Entity-the_paper.description: The paper presents a new theory of discourse structure that emphasizes the interrelated components of linguistic structure, intentional structure, and attentional state, and illustrates this theory with examples of discourse phenomena.

Entity-discourse.label: discourse
Entity-discourse.description: In this paper, 'discourse' refers to the structured sequence of utterances that encompasses linguistic, intentional, and attentional components, highlighting the dynamic interactions and purposes within communication.

Entity-component.label: components
Entity-component.description: The term 'components' refers to the three interrelated elements of discourse structure in the proposed theory, specifically the linguistic structure, intentional structure, and attentional state.

Entity-the_distinction_among_these_compo.label: the distinction among these components
Entity-the_distinction_among_these_compo.description: The distinction among these components refers to the differentiation between the linguistic structure, intentional structure, and attentional state in discourse theory, which is crucial for understanding various discourse phenomena.

Entity-discourse-relevant_purpose.label: discourse-relevant purposes
Entity-discourse-relevant_purpose.description: The term 'discourse-relevant purposes' refers to the intentions and goals that are expressed within the segments of discourse, which are essential for understanding the relationships among utterances in the context of a new theory of discourse structure.

Entity-the_structure_of_the_sequence_of_.label: the structure of the sequence of utterances
aliases: the structure of the sequence of utterances
Entity-the_structure_of_the_sequence_of_.description: The structure of the sequence of utterances, referred to as the linguistic structure, is a component of discourse structure that organizes utterances into coherent segments based on their natural aggregation within the discourse.

mentions.local_name: the structure of the sequence of utterances

Entity-property_of_discourse.label: properties of discourse
Entity-property_of_discourse.description: The properties of discourse refer to the characteristics and features of discourse that influence how utterances are structured, understood, and processed, including aspects such as linguistic structure, intentional structure, and attentional state.

Entity-discourse_structure.label: discourse structure
Entity-discourse_structure.description: Discourse structure refers to the organizational framework that governs the arrangement and interrelation of segments within a discourse, influencing how meaning is constructed and understood in communication.

Entity-attentional_state.label: attentional state
Entity-attentional_state.description: The attentional state refers to the dynamic focus of attention of participants in a discourse, which records the salient objects, properties, and relations at each moment as the discourse unfolds.

Entity-this_processing_description.label: This processing description
Entity-this_processing_description.description: This processing description refers to the framework that outlines how discourse processing involves recognizing the aggregation of utterances, the intentions expressed within them, and the dynamic attentional state of participants, emphasizing the importance of both discourse information and participants' domain knowledge.

Entity-behaviour_of_cue_phrase__referrin.label: behaviour of cue phrases, referring expressions, and interruptions
aliases: behaviour of cue phrases, referring expressions, and interruptions
Entity-behaviour_of_cue_phrase__referrin.description: The behaviour of cue phrases, referring expressions, and interruptions refers to the patterns and functions of these linguistic elements within discourse, as they contribute to the structure, purpose, and attentional dynamics of communication.

mentions.local_name: behaviour of cue phrases, referring expressions, and interruptions

Entity-segment_of_the_discourse.label: segments of the discourse
Entity-segment_of_the_discourse.description: Segments of the discourse refer to the natural groupings of utterances within a discourse that form the linguistic structure, facilitating the analysis of how these utterances aggregate and relate to each other.

Entity-framework_for_describing_the_proc.label: framework for describing the processing of utterances
aliases: a framework for describing the processing of utterances in a discourse
framework for describing the processing of utterances
Entity-framework_for_describing_the_proc.description: The 'framework for describing the processing of utterances' refers to a theoretical model that delineates how utterances in discourse are structured, their associated purposes, and the attentional states of participants, facilitating the understanding of discourse phenomena such as cue phrases and interruptions.

mentions.local_name: framework for describing the processing of utterances
a framework for describing the processing of utterances in a discourse

Entity-processing.label: processing
Entity-processing.description: In the context of the paper, 'processing' refers to the cognitive and analytical activities involved in understanding and managing the structure, intentions, and attentional states of discourse as it unfolds.

Entity-the_attentional_state.label: the attentional state
aliases: the state of focus of attention
Entity-the_attentional_state.description: The attentional state refers to a dynamic abstraction that captures the focus of attention of discourse participants, recording the salient objects, properties, and relations at each moment during the unfolding of discourse.

mentions.local_name: the state of focus of attention

Entity-intention.label: intention
Entity-intention.description: In the context of discourse structure, 'intention' refers to the discourse-relevant purposes that are expressed within linguistic segments and the relationships among these purposes.

Entity-theory_of_attention.label: theory of attention
Entity-theory_of_attention.description: The theory of attention refers to a conceptual framework within discourse structure that focuses on the dynamic state of attention of participants, capturing salient objects, properties, and relations during discourse processing.

Entity-example_discourse.label: example discourses
Entity-example_discourse.description: The term 'example discourses' refers to specific instances of discourse used in the paper to illustrate the proposed theory of discourse structure, which emphasizes the roles of attention, intention, and the aggregation of utterances.

Entity-linguistic_structure.label: linguistic structure
Entity-linguistic_structure.description: Linguistic structure refers to the arrangement and organization of elements within language, including the sequence and relationships of utterances in discourse.

Entity-tracking_the_discourse_through_th.label: tracking the discourse through the operation of the mechanisms associated with attentional state
aliases: tracking the discourse through the operation of the mechanisms associated with attentional state
Entity-tracking_the_discourse_through_th.description: The entity 'tracking the discourse through the operation of the mechanisms associated with attentional state' refers to the process of monitoring and understanding the flow of discourse by utilizing the dynamic focus of attention of participants, which influences how utterances are aggregated and intentions are recognized.

mentions.local_name: tracking the discourse through the operation of the mechanisms associated with attentional state

Entity-mechanism_associated_with_attenti.label: mechanisms associated with attentional state
Entity-mechanism_associated_with_attenti.description: The term 'mechanisms associated with attentional state' refers to the cognitive processes that enable the tracking and management of focus and salience of objects, properties, and relations during discourse, facilitating the recognition of utterance aggregation and intention relationships.

Entity-recognizing_the_intention_express.label: recognizing the intentions expressed in the discourse
aliases: recognizing the intentions expressed in the discourse
Entity-recognizing_the_intention_express.description: Recognizing the intentions expressed in the discourse refers to the process of identifying the purposes and meanings behind the utterances in a conversation, which is essential for understanding the overall structure and dynamics of the discourse.

mentions.local_name: recognizing the intentions expressed in the discourse

Entity-processing_of_utterance.label: processing of utterances
Entity-processing_of_utterance.description: The processing of utterances refers to the cognitive and linguistic mechanisms involved in recognizing, aggregating, and interpreting the sequences of spoken or written expressions within a discourse, including understanding their intentions and the relationships among them.

Entity-aggregation_of_utterance.label: aggregation of utterances
Entity-aggregation_of_utterance.description: The 'aggregation of utterances' refers to the process by which individual spoken or written utterances are grouped into coherent segments within a discourse, forming part of a theoretical framework that examines the structure and processing of discourse.

Entity-utterance_of_the_discourse.label: utterances of the discourse
Entity-utterance_of_the_discourse.description: The term 'utterances of the discourse' refers to the individual spoken or written segments of communication that collectively form a discourse, which are analyzed in terms of their aggregation into meaningful segments, the intentions they express, and their relationships within the overall structure of the discourse.

Entity-information_from_the_discourse.label: information from the discourse
Entity-information_from_the_discourse.description: The phrase 'information from the discourse' refers to the data and insights derived from the structure, purposes, and attentional states present in a discourse, which are essential for understanding and processing the interactions and intentions of participants.

Entity-relationship_among_them.label: relationships among them
Entity-relationship_among_them.description: The term 'relationships among them' refers to the connections and interactions between the discourse-relevant purposes expressed in the linguistic segments of discourse, as part of the intentional structure in the theory of discourse structure presented in the paper.

Entity-relationship_among_intention.label: relationships among intentions
Entity-relationship_among_intention.description: The term 'relationships among intentions' refers to the connections and interactions between various purposes expressed within discourse segments, which are essential for understanding the overall structure and processing of discourse.

Entity-tracking_the_discourse.label: tracking the discourse
Entity-tracking_the_discourse.description: Tracking the discourse refers to the process of monitoring and understanding the dynamic attentional state of participants during discourse, which involves recognizing how utterances aggregate into segments and the intentions expressed within those segments.

Entity-recognizing_how_the_utterance_of_.label: recognizing how the utterances of the discourse aggregate into segments
aliases: recognizing how the utterances of the discourse aggregate into segments
Entity-recognizing_how_the_utterance_of_.description: The entity refers to the cognitive process involved in identifying and organizing the utterances within a discourse into coherent segments, which is essential for understanding the structure and meaning of the discourse.

mentions.local_name: recognizing how the utterances of the discourse aggregate into segments

Entity-processing_description.label: processing description
Entity-processing_description.description: The processing description refers to a detailed explanation of how information from discourse and participants' knowledge is utilized in recognizing utterances, intentions, and attentional states within the framework of discourse processing.

Entity-intention_expressed_in_the_discou.label: intentions expressed in the discourse
Entity-intention_expressed_in_the_discou.description: The term 'intentions expressed in the discourse' refers to the specific purposes or goals that are conveyed through the segments of utterances in a discourse, which are essential for understanding the relationships among these intentions and the overall structure of the discourse.

Entity-linguistic_segment.label: linguistic segments
Entity-linguistic_segment.description: Linguistic segments refer to the distinct portions of discourse that aggregate utterances based on their natural coherence and relevance to the discourse's purpose.

Entity-relation.label: relations
Entity-relation.description: In the context of discourse structure, 'relations' refers to the connections and associations among the intentions expressed in linguistic segments, as well as the dynamic interactions of objects and properties that are salient during the discourse.

Entity-discourse_phenomenon.label: discourse phenomena
Entity-discourse_phenomenon.description: Discourse phenomena refer to various observable events and patterns in communication that occur during spoken or written interactions, including elements like cue phrases, referring expressions, and interruptions.

Entity-relationship.label: relationships
Entity-relationship.description: In the context of discourse structure, 'relationships' refers to the connections and interactions among the discourse-relevant purposes expressed in the linguistic segments.

Entity-interruption.label: interruptions
Entity-interruption.description: Interruptions refer to a specific type of discourse phenomenon that disrupts the flow of communication, highlighting the dynamic nature of attentional states and the interaction of utterances within a discourse.

Entity-information.label: information
Entity-information.description: In the context of discourse processing, 'information' refers to the data derived from the discourse itself and the knowledge that participants possess about the domain, which is essential for recognizing utterance segments, intentions, and attentional states.

Entity-discourse_processing.label: Discourse processing
Entity-discourse_processing.description: Discourse processing is a field of study in linguistics that involves the analysis and understanding of how language is used in communication, focusing on the structure and function of spoken or written discourse.

Entity-cue_phrase.label: cue phrases
Entity-cue_phrase.description: Cue phrases are linguistic elements that signal the structure or organization of discourse, helping to guide the listener's understanding of the conversation.

Entity-the_focus_of_attention.label: the focus of attention
Entity-the_focus_of_attention.description: The focus of attention refers to the dynamic abstraction that captures the salient objects, properties, and relations that participants in a discourse are concentrating on as the conversation progresses.

Entity-participant.label: participants
Entity-participant.description: The term 'participants' refers to the individuals engaged in the discourse, whose focus of attention is dynamically represented in the attentional state as the conversation progresses.

Entity-utterance.label: utterances
Entity-utterance.description: Utterances are distinct segments of spoken or written communication that convey meaning and can function as individual speech acts within a discourse.

Entity-the_role_of_information.label: the role of information
Entity-the_role_of_information.description: The role of information refers to the significance of data derived from discourse and participants' domain knowledge in recognizing and processing utterances within a discourse structure.

Entity-property.label: properties
Entity-property.description: In the context of discourse structure, 'properties' refers to the characteristics and attributes of objects and relations that are significant and noteworthy at specific moments during the unfolding of discourse.

Entity-object.label: objects
Entity-object.description: In the context of discourse processing, 'objects' refers to the entities, properties, and relations that are significant and noteworthy to the participants during the unfolding of the discourse.

Entity-referring_expression.label: referring expressions
Entity-referring_expression.description: Referring expressions are linguistic elements used in discourse to denote or identify entities, allowing speakers and listeners to understand who or what is being talked about.

Entity-participant__knowledge.label: participants' knowledge
Entity-participant__knowledge.description: Participants' knowledge refers to the cognitive resources and understanding that individuals possess regarding the domain of discourse, which are utilized in processing and interpreting the information presented during discourse.

Entity-domain.label: domain
Entity-domain.description: In this context, 'domain' refers to the specific area of knowledge or field of study that participants draw upon to understand and process the discourse.

Entity-focus_of_attention.label: focus of attention
Entity-focus_of_attention.description: The focus of attention refers to the specific cognitive state or mental process in which an individual directs their awareness or concentration towards a particular object, idea, or aspect of their environment.

Entity-participant__knowledge_of_the_dom.label: participants' knowledge of the domain
aliases: the participants' knowledge of the domain
Entity-participant__knowledge_of_the_dom.description: Participants' knowledge of the domain refers to the understanding and information that individuals possess about a specific subject area, which is crucial for processing and interpreting discourse effectively.

mentions.local_name: the participants' knowledge of the domain

Entity-recognition_task.label: recognition tasks
Entity-recognition_task.description: Recognition tasks are cognitive activities that involve identifying and interpreting information based on prior knowledge and contextual cues.

Entity-paper.label: paper
Entity-paper.description: A paper is a written work that presents research findings, theories, or analyses, typically published in an academic or professional context.

Entity-knowledge_of_the_domain.label: knowledge of the domain
Entity-knowledge_of_the_domain.description: knowledge of the domain refers to the understanding and expertise in a specific area or field, enabling individuals to effectively interpret and engage with relevant information and tasks.

summary: In this paper we explore a new theory of discourse structure that stresses the role of purpose and processing in discourse . In this theory , discourse structure is composed of three separate but interrelated components : the structure of the sequence of utterances -LRB- called the linguistic structure -RRB- , a structure of purposes -LRB- called the intentional structure -RRB- , and the state of focus of attention -LRB- called the attentional state -RRB- . The linguistic structure consists of segments of the discourse into which the utterances naturally aggregate . The intentional structure captures the discourse-relevant purposes , expressed in each of the linguistic segments as well as relationships among them . The attentional state is an abstraction of the focus of attention of the participants as the discourse unfolds . The attentional state , being dynamic , records the objects , properties , and relations that are salient at each point of the discourse . The distinction among these components is essential to provide an adequate explanation of such discourse phenomena as cue phrases , referring expressions , and interruptions . The theory of attention , intention , and aggregation of utterances is illustrated in the paper with a number of example discourses . Various properties of discourse are described , and explanations for the behaviour of cue phrases , referring expressions , and interruptions are explored . This theory provides a framework for describing the processing of utterances in a discourse . Discourse processing requires recognizing how the utterances of the discourse aggregate into segments , recognizing the intentions expressed in the discourse and the relationships among intentions , and tracking the discourse through the operation of the mechanisms associated with attentional state . This processing description specifies in these recognition tasks the role of information from the discourse and from the participants ' knowledge of the domain .

Predicate-explores.label: explores
Predicate-explores.description: The predicate 'explores' indicates an active engagement or investigation by the subject into the object, suggesting a process of inquiry, examination, or analysis aimed at gaining a deeper understanding or insight into the object. It implies that the subject is delving into the complexities, nuances, or details of the object, often leading to the discovery of new information or perspectives.

Predicate-stresses.label: stresses
Predicate-stresses.description: The predicate 'stresses' indicates an emphasis or highlight placed by the subject on the object, suggesting that the subject prioritizes or underscores the importance of the object in a particular context. This connection implies that the subject conveys a significant focus or attention towards the object, often to elucidate its relevance or to draw the audience's awareness to it.

Predicate-is_composed_of.label: is composed of
Predicate-is_composed_of.description: The predicate 'is composed of' indicates a relationship where the subject is made up of multiple elements or parts, which together form a cohesive whole. It emphasizes the structural or organizational aspect of the subject, highlighting how the individual components contribute to its overall identity or function.

Predicate-includes.label: includes
Predicate-includes.description: The predicate 'includes' serves to establish a relationship between the subject and the object by indicating that the subject encompasses or contains the object as a part or element of its overall composition. It suggests that the object is an integral component that contributes to the understanding or definition of the subject.

Predicate-is_called.label: is called
Predicate-is_called.description: The predicate 'is called' serves to establish a naming or identification relationship between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject is referred to or recognized by the term or phrase represented by the object. This predicate is commonly used to define or label concepts, entities, or phenomena, thereby providing clarity and understanding of the subject's identity or nature.

Predicate-consists_of.label: consists of
Predicate-consists_of.description: The predicate 'consists of' indicates a relationship where the subject is composed of or made up of the elements represented by the object. It implies that the object is a fundamental part or component that collectively forms the whole represented by the subject.

Predicate-captures.label: captures
Predicate-captures.description: The predicate 'captures' indicates a relationship where the subject effectively encompasses, represents, or conveys the essence or characteristics of the object. It suggests that the subject has the ability to seize or embody the qualities, features, or intentions associated with the object, thereby creating a meaningful connection between the two.

Predicate-expressed_in.label: expressed in
Predicate-expressed_in.description: The predicate 'expressed in' indicates a relationship where the subject is conveyed, represented, or manifested through the object. It suggests that the subject's qualities, characteristics, or intentions are articulated or realized within the framework of the object, highlighting the medium or form through which the subject is communicated.

Predicate-is_an_abstraction_of.label: is an abstraction of
Predicate-is_an_abstraction_of.description: The predicate 'is an abstraction of' indicates a relationship where the subject represents a generalized or simplified concept that encapsulates the essential characteristics or qualities of the object. This relationship suggests that the subject serves as a conceptual framework or model that helps to understand or interpret the more specific or concrete nature of the object.

Predicate-of.label: of
Predicate-of.description: The predicate 'of' indicates a relationship of belonging or association between the subject and the object. It signifies that the subject is a defining characteristic, component, or aspect of the object, establishing a connection that often implies possession, origin, or relevance.

Predicate-as_the_discourse_unfolds.label: as the discourse unfolds
Predicate-as_the_discourse_unfolds.description: The predicate 'as the discourse unfolds' indicates a temporal relationship where the subject is actively engaged in or influencing the development of the object over time. It suggests that the dynamics, interactions, or changes occurring within the subject are integral to the progression and evolution of the discourse, highlighting a continuous and evolving process.

Predicate-records.label: records
Predicate-records.description: The predicate 'records' indicates an action or process whereby the subject captures, stores, or documents information, data, or events related to the object. It implies a relationship in which the subject actively engages in the act of preserving or noting down the characteristics, occurrences, or details of the object, thereby creating a reference or account that can be accessed or analyzed later.

Predicate-is_essential_to_provide_an_ade.label: is essential to provide an adequate explanation of
Predicate-is_essential_to_provide_an_ade.description: The predicate 'is essential to provide an adequate explanation of' indicates that the subject is a crucial element or factor necessary for delivering a comprehensive and satisfactory understanding of the object. It implies that without the subject, the explanation of the object would be insufficient or incomplete, highlighting the importance of the relationship between the two.

Predicate-is_illustrated_in.label: is illustrated in
Predicate-is_illustrated_in.description: The predicate 'is illustrated in' serves to establish a relationship where the subject is represented or exemplified through the object. It indicates that the object provides a visual, textual, or conceptual representation that clarifies, explains, or demonstrates the subject's concepts, theories, or ideas.

Predicate-contains.label: contains
Predicate-contains.description: The predicate 'contains' indicates that the subject includes or holds within it the object, suggesting a relationship where the object is a part of or is present within the subject. This relationship implies that the subject has the capacity to encompass the object, whether physically, conceptually, or contextually.

Predicate-are_described.label: are described
Predicate-are_described.description: The predicate 'are described' serves to establish a relationship where the subject is characterized or explained in relation to the object. It indicates that the subject possesses certain attributes, qualities, or features that are articulated or conveyed through the object. This connection implies that the subject is being represented or defined by the information provided in the object.

Predicate-are_explored.label: are explored
Predicate-are_explored.description: The predicate 'are explored' indicates an investigative or analytical process in which the subject is examined or studied in relation to the object. It suggests that the subject is being scrutinized to uncover insights, patterns, or relationships concerning the object, thereby enhancing understanding of the subject's characteristics or functions.

Predicate-provides.label: provides
Predicate-provides.description: The predicate 'provides' indicates a relationship in which the subject offers, supplies, or makes available a particular resource, support, or framework to the object. It suggests that the subject plays an active role in facilitating or enabling the object, which typically represents a concept, tool, or method that can be utilized or applied in a specific context.

Predicate-requires.label: requires
Predicate-requires.description: The predicate 'requires' establishes a relationship in which the subject is dependent on the object for its execution, functionality, or realization. It indicates that the subject cannot be fully achieved or understood without the presence or fulfillment of the object, suggesting a necessary condition or prerequisite that must be met.

Predicate-aggregate_into.label: aggregate into
Predicate-aggregate_into.description: The predicate 'aggregate into' denotes a process in which individual elements or components (the subject) come together to form a larger, unified whole (the object). This implies a transformation or organization of the subject's parts into a more complex structure, highlighting the relationship of accumulation and synthesis between the two entities.

Predicate-have.label: have
Predicate-have.description: The predicate 'have' denotes a possession or ownership relationship between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject possesses, contains, or is associated with the object in some meaningful way. In the context of the example triple, it suggests that the subject (intention) possesses or is characterized by the object (relationships among intentions), highlighting a connection where the subject is defined or influenced by the presence of the object.

Predicate-track.label: track
Predicate-track.description: The predicate 'track' denotes the action of monitoring, observing, or following the progress or development of a subject in relation to an object. It implies a continuous or systematic engagement with the object, allowing the subject to maintain awareness of changes, patterns, or relevant information pertaining to the object over time.

Predicate-specifies.label: specifies
Predicate-specifies.description: The predicate 'specifies' indicates a relationship where the subject provides detailed information or clarification about the object, defining its characteristics, role, or meaning in a particular context.

Predicate-from.label: from
Predicate-from.description: The predicate 'from' indicates a source or origin relationship between the subject and the object, suggesting that the subject derives, originates, or is influenced by the object in some manner. It establishes a directional connection where the subject is understood to be associated with or receiving input, context, or characteristics from the object.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates that the subject is introducing, showcasing, or delivering information, findings, or concepts related to the object. It implies a communicative act where the subject conveys knowledge or insights about the object to an audience, often in a structured or formal manner.

Predicate-is_a_framework_for_understandi.label: is a framework for understanding
Predicate-is_a_framework_for_understandi.description: The predicate 'is a framework for understanding' establishes a relationship where the subject provides a structured approach or conceptual model that aids in comprehending the object. It implies that the subject offers insights, principles, or methodologies that facilitate the interpretation or analysis of the object, thereby enhancing the understanding of the concepts or phenomena represented by the object.

Predicate-illustrates.label: illustrates
Predicate-illustrates.description: The predicate 'illustrates' serves to establish a relationship where the subject provides a representation, example, or clarification of the object. It indicates that the subject conveys or demonstrates the concepts, ideas, or principles encapsulated in the object, thereby enhancing understanding or providing insight into the subject matter.

Predicate-is_a_specific_application_of.label: is a specific application of
Predicate-is_a_specific_application_of.description: The predicate 'is a specific application of' establishes a relationship where the subject represents a particular instance or implementation that derives from a broader concept or framework denoted by the object. This indicates that the subject is a specialized or concrete example that utilizes the principles, ideas, or methodologies encapsulated in the object, thereby demonstrating how theoretical constructs can be operationalized in specific contexts.

Predicate-is_a_component_of.label: is a component of
Predicate-is_a_component_of.description: The predicate 'is a component of' indicates a relationship where the subject is an integral part or element that contributes to the overall structure, function, or understanding of the object. This implies that the subject cannot be fully understood or appreciated without recognizing its role within the context of the object, which represents a broader system or concept.

Predicate-is_one_of.label: is one of
Predicate-is_one_of.description: The predicate 'is one of' establishes a relationship of inclusion or membership between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a part of a larger set or category represented by the object. It implies that the subject shares characteristics or qualities with other elements within the object, which collectively define a broader concept or framework.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a more specific concept or instance that falls under the wider category represented by the object. This relationship suggests that the object encompasses a broader scope or definition that includes the subject as a subset, thereby illustrating the organization of knowledge or concepts within a particular domain.
